review.title: Towards an Ontology-Driven Blockchain Design for Supply Chain Provenance
review.abstract: An interesting research problem in our age of Big Data is that of determining provenance. Granular evaluation of provenance of physical goods--e.g. tracking ingredients of a pharmaceutical or demonstrating authenticity of luxury goods--has often not been possible with today's items that are produced and transported in complex, inter-organizational, often internationally-spanning supply chains. Recent adoption of Internet of Things and Blockchain technologies give promise at better supply chain provenance. We are particularly interested in the blockchain as many favoured use cases of blockchain are for provenance tracking. We are also interested in applying ontologies as there has been some work done on knowledge provenance, traceability, and food provenance using ontologies. In this paper, we make a case for why ontologies can contribute to blockchain design. To support this case, we analyze a traceability ontology and translate some of its representations to smart contracts that execute a provenance trace and enforce traceability constraints on the Ethereum blockchain platform.

Granular evaluation of the provenance of physical goods - such as tracking the ingredients of a medicine or proving the authenticity of luxury goods - has often not been possible with today's products, which are produced and transported in complex, interorganizational and often cross-international supply chains. Recent adoption of the Internet of Things and blockchain technologies promises to improve the provenance of the supply chain. We are particularly interested in blockchain, as many preferred use cases of blockchain serve to trace provenance. To support this case, we are analyzing ontologies, as some work has been done on provenance, traceability and food origin using ontologies. In this paper, we explain why ontologies can contribute to blockchain design.

sections.heading: Traceability Ontology Based Blockchain for Provenance
sections.text: As already mentioned, blockchain startups like provenance.org and skuchain are working on the provenance of the supply chain. However, there seems to be no other work than our own efforts to take an ontology-based approach. There have been some related works that use ontologies, though not block chain-related. Perhaps the most comprehensive is traceability ontology (Kim et al. 1995), which served as a key component of TOVE Ontologies for Enterprise Modeling (Fox and Gruninger 1998). Interestingly, this traceability work has attracted interest among food scientists (Dabbene et al. 2014) (Regattieri et al. 2007). Food science has adopted an ontology that tended to model manufacturing companies to ensure food safety along the food supply chain.
